Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Using big data, AI, and machine learning in gender equality and social inclusion analysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to enable economic development aid organizations to plan, implement, measure, and achieve better gender equality and social inclusion outcomes. Gender equality is recognized as an important factor in catalyzing development and lifting communities out of poverty. Empowered women contribute to healthy and productive families, communities, and nations. An important step in doing this is to integrate high quality and timely gender analysis (examination of how differences in gender roles, activities, needs, and opportunities affect men, women, girls and boys in specific contexts), into decision-making and project planning. For both public and private sectors, early, action-oriented gender analysis is vital to tackle improve outcomes. In 2015 - 2016, OECD aid agencies spent, on average, $41.7 billion per year targeting gender equality and women's empowerment. Conservatively estimating that 3-5% of this expenditure is for gender analysis and action planning, that makes a market of $1.3-2.1 billion in the development sector alone. This project can potentially improve outcomes from that development funding.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to develop and test a web-based application that automates the currently manual process of conducting gender analyses. This addresses a real world challenge faced by aid organizations to effectively integrate gender analyses into planning to inform effective and timely decision-making. Despite being a requirement by many organizations, there are procurement and contract delays, shortage of gender experts, and manual research and data collection. This project will develop a machine learning model that leverages big data, APIs, and text-mining, driven by an analytic framework created by experts, to automate this process and deliver customized results instantly for a fraction of the cost. Phase I will build, train, and test the model for one sector and select countries. By the end of Phase I, the model will be tested and iterated to meet high quality control standards. Once validated, it will be ready to scale globally across sectors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the NSF SBIR Phase I grant period, Equilo conducted customer discovery, built a functional minimal viable product that lays the groundwork for machine learning, and tested it both internally for functionality and externally with select users. All planned Phase I work plan milestones were achieved , which resulted in the successful build of the three functional components of the application:

  1. Algorithm and coding development that uses frontend inputs to execute a multi-level workflow to extract data from the backend database

  2. Development of database backend which houses country-specific, sector-specific metadata (e.g., qualitative and quantitative data points) in a centralized database

  3. Content generation that produces output deliverables accessible via a user’s online dashboard as well as downloadable in PDF or DOC file


Customer discovery that began at the onset of the grant period provided valuable feedback that confirmed Equilo’starget market does have a tangible need for this solution. A potential end-user at the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) stated, “I know [gender analysis] is important and I have to do it, but when I think about the data required, analyzing it, and making sense of it…it makes me want to jump out the window.” This is the motivation behind Equilo—to deliver synthesized, easily consumable data to practitioners via an interactive dashboard that they can use to improve development project and investment impact. 

In approaching product development, data has been at the forefront of Equilo’s AI journey, recognizing the importance of a strong data architecture foundation in order to layer more advanced analytics and AI models at scale. During Phase I, significant time was spent on data preprocessing - identifying and bringing together disparate data sets, validating and cleaning the data, then organizing and tagging. Another focus was on developing a model analytical framework for the clean energy sector that serves as the blueprint for the artificial neural network used in the MVP. Part of our mission is to make it extremely easy for users to engage with the tool to increase the likelihood of adoption and ultimately lead to better outcomes for project beneficiaries. 

This grant enabled Equilo to gather valuable feedback and insights from potential end users on areas to innovate and improve with the next iteration. The user testing of the final minimal viable product provided both positive and constructive feedback on existing functionality and ideas for features in future iterations. User testing was conducted first with the internal team and then with select customers from our initial primary target market including international development agencies, development finance institutions, NGOs, and development consulting firms. Overwhelmingly, the majority of users reported that the Equilo dashboard is easy to navigate, that the quality and the content is better than what they currently access through alternative means, and that they would be likely to use the tool, allocate team resources and recommend to others. At the same time, users provided thoughtful and constructive feedback from which the Equilo team is learning and identifying how to make valuable improvements in the next iteration  

In summary, the NSF SBIR Phase I supported Equilo’s R&D to reach a critical point in development preparing to transition from an MVP to the next future phase of building Equilo V1.0, which will be our first market-ready product. Given the significant interest expressed by customers coupled with the completion of the Phase I objectives, plus the identification of new opportunities for innovation, Equilo is prepared to move forward with the next phase of product development putting us on the path to scale globally and accelerate impact to improve gender equality. 


 


Last Modified: 11/15/2019
Modified by: Jessica Menon
